In [[physics]], the '''reduced mass''' is the "effective" [[Mass#Inertial mass|inertial mass]] appearing in the [[two-body problem]] of [[Newtonian mechanics]]. It is a quantity which allows the two-body problem to be solved as if it were a [[one-body problem]]. Note, however, that the mass determining the [[gravitational force]] is ''not'' reduced. In the computation one mass ''can'' be replaced with the reduced mass, if this is compensated by replacing the other mass with the sum of both masses. The reduced mass is frequently denoted by <math> \mu </math> ([[Mu (letter)|mu]]), although the [[standard gravitational parameter]] is also denoted by <math> \mu </math> (as are [[Mu (letter)#Physics and engineering|a number of other physical quantities]]). It has the [[dimensional analysis|dimensions]] of mass, and [[SI unit]] kg.
==Equation==
Given two bodies, one with mass ''m''<sub>1</sub> and the other with mass ''m''<sub>2</sub>, the equivalent one-body problem, with the position of one body with respect to the other as the unknown, is that of a single body of mass<ref>Encyclopaedia of Physics (2nd Edition), R.G. Lerner, G.L. Trigg, VHC publishers, 1991, (Verlagsgesellschaft) 3-527-26954-1, (VHC Inc.) 0-89573-752-3</ref><ref>Dynamics and Relativity, J.R. Forshaw, A.G. Smith, Wiley, 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-470-01460-8}}</ref>
:<math>\mu = \cfrac{1}{\cfrac{1}{m_1}+\cfrac{1}{m_2}} = \cfrac{m_1 m_2}{m_1 + m_2},\!\,</math>
where the force on this mass is given by the force between the two bodies.
===Properties===
The reduced mass is always less than or equal to the mass of each body:
:<math>\mu \leq m_1, \quad \mu \leq m_2 \!\,</math>
and has the reciprocal additive property:
:<math>\frac{1}{\mu} = \frac{1}{m_1} + \frac{1}{m_2} \,\!</math>
which by re-arrangement is equivalent to half of the [[harmonic mean]].
In the special case that <math>m_1 = m_2</math>:
:<math>{\mu} = \frac{m_1}{2} = \frac{m_2}{2}\,\!</math>
If <math>m_1 \gg m_2</math>, then <math>\mu \approx m_2</math>.
==Derivation==
The equation can be derived as follows.
===Newtonian mechanics===
{{main|Newtonian mechanics}}
Using [[Newton's second law]], the force exerted by body 2 on body 1 is :<math>\mathbf{F}_{12} = m_1 \mathbf{a}_1. \!\,</math>
The force exerted by body 1 on body 2 is
:<math>\mathbf{F}_{21} = m_2 \mathbf{a}_2. \!\,</math>
According to [[Newton's third law]], the force that body 2 exerts on body 1 is equal and opposite to the force that body 1 exerts on body 2:
:<math>\mathbf{F}_{12} = - \mathbf{F}_{21}.\!\,</math>
Therefore, :<math>m_1 \mathbf{a}_1 = - m_2 \mathbf{a}_2. \!\,</math>
and
:<math>\mathbf{a}_2=-{m_1 \over m_2} \mathbf{a}_1. \!\,</math>
The relative acceleration '''a'''<sub>rel</sub> between the two bodies is given by
:<math>\mathbf{a}_{\rm rel}= \mathbf{a}_1-\mathbf{a}_2 = \left(1+\frac{m_1}{m_2}\right) \mathbf{a}_1 = \frac{m_2+m_1}{m_1 m_2} m_1 \mathbf{a}_1 = \frac{\mathbf{F}_{12}}{\mu}. </math>
So we conclude that body 1 moves with respect to the position of body 2 as a body of mass equal to the reduced mass.
===Lagrangian mechanics===
{{main|Lagrangian mechanics}}
Alternatively, a Lagrangian description of the two-body problem gives a [[Lagrangian mechanics|Lagrangian]] of
:<math>L = {1 \over 2} m_1 \mathbf{\dot{r}}_1^2 + {1 \over 2} m_2 \mathbf{\dot{r}}_2^2 - V(| \mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_2 | ) \!\,</math>
where <math>{\mathbf{r}}_{i}</math> is the position vector of mass <math>m_{i}</math> (of particle ''<math>i</math>''). The potential energy ''V'' is a function as it is only dependent on the absolute distance between the particles. If we define :<math>\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_2 </math> and let the centre of mass coincide with our origin in this reference frame, i.e. :<math> m_1 \mathbf{r}_1 + m_2 \mathbf{r}_2 = 0 </math>, then :<math> \mathbf{r}_1 = \frac{m_2 \mathbf{r}}{m_1 + m_2} , \; \mathbf{r}_2 = -\frac{m_1 \mathbf{r}}{m_1 + m_2}.</math>
Then substituting above gives a new Lagrangian
:<math> L = {1 \over 2}\mu \mathbf{\dot{r}}^2 - V(r), </math>
where
:<math>\mu = \frac{m_1 m_2}{m_1 + m_2} </math>
is the reduced mass. Thus we have reduced the two-body problem to that of one body.
==Applications==
Reduced mass can be used in a multitude of two-body problems, where classical mechanics is applicable.
===Moment of inertia of two point masses in a line===
In a system with two point masses m<sub>1</sub> and m<sub>2</sub> such that they are co-linear, the [[center of mass]] may be found via
<math>x_{cm} = \frac{m_1x_1 + m_2x_2}{m_1+m_2}</math>.
The [[moment of inertia]] of this system in the center of mass frame of reference is a two-body problem with two masses, each with its own distance to the center of mass. By converting to the equivalent reduced mass [[frame of reference]], the system may be treated as a single reduced mass, μ, with a distance, d, equal to the sum of x<sub>1</sub> and x<sub>2</sub>. This is because the rotational axis of the reduced mass frame of reference is through the combined mass, M (the sum of m<sub>1</sub> and m<sub>2</sub>)
[[File:MOIaboutCOMaxis3.svg]][[File:MOIaboutCOMaxis4.svg]]
<math>M=m_1+m_2</math>
<math>d=x_1+x_2</math>
<math>\mu = \frac{m_1 m_2}{m_1+m_2} = \frac{m_1 m_2}{M}</math>
The combined mass M is eliminated in the determination of the moment of inertia of the system since it is a point particle (making M the same size as μ, but with greater mass. Images not drawn to scale) along the axis of rotation (via the [[parallel axis theorem]], it's contribution of MR<sup>2</sup> would be zero since R=0 because M and μ are ''also'' point masses). Determining the moment of inertia of the reduced mass (μ) system is equivalent to determining the moment of inertia of the center of mass system.
<math>{\displaystyle I={\frac {m_{1}m_{2}}{m_{1}\!+\!m_{2}}}d^{2}=\mu d^{2}} </math>
===Collisions of particles===
In a collision with a [[coefficient of restitution]] ''e'', the change in kinetic energy can be written as
:<math>\Delta K = \frac{1}{2}\mu v^2_{\rm rel}(e^2-1)</math>,
where v<sub>rel</sub> is the relative velocity of the bodies before [[collision]].
For typical applications in nuclear physics, where one particle's mass is much larger than the other the reduced mass can be approximated as the smaller mass of the system. The limit of the reduced mass formula as one mass goes to infinity is the smaller mass, thus this approximation is used to ease calculations, especially when the larger particle's exact mass is not known.
===Motion of two massive bodies under their gravitational attraction===
In the case of the gravitational potential energy :<math>V(| \mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_2 | ) = - \frac{G m_1 m_2}{| \mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_2 |} \, ,</math> we find that the position of the first body with respect to the second is governed by the same differential equation as the position of a body with the reduced mass orbiting a body with a mass equal to the sum of the two masses, because
:<math>m_1 m_2 = (m_1+m_2) \mu\!\,</math>
===Non-relativistic quantum mechanics===
Consider the [[electron]] (mass ''m<sub>e</sub>'') and [[proton]] (mass ''m<sub>p</sub>'') in the [[hydrogen atom]].<ref>Molecular Quantum Mechanics Parts I and II: An Introduction to Quantum Chemistry (Volume 1), P.W. Atkins, Oxford University Press, 1977, {{ISBN|0-19-855129-0}}</ref> They orbit each other about a common centre of mass, a two body problem. To analyze the motion of the electron, a one-body problem, the reduced mass replaces the electron mass
:<math>m_e \rightarrow \frac{m_em_p}{m_e+m_p} </math>
and the proton mass becomes the sum of the two masses
:<math>m_p \rightarrow m_e + m_p </math>
This idea is used to set up the [[Schrödinger equation]] for the hydrogen atom.
===Other uses===
"Reduced mass" may also refer more generally to an [[algebra]]ic term of the form {{Citation needed|date=December 2011}}
:<math>x^* = {1 \over {1 \over x_1} + {1 \over x_2}} = {x_1 x_2 \over x_1 + x_2}\!\,</math>
that simplifies an equation of the form
:<math>\ {1\over x^*} = \sum_{i=1}^n {1\over x_i} = {1\over x_1} + {1\over x_2} + \cdots+ {1\over x_n}.\!\,</math>
The reduced mass is typically used as a relationship between two system elements in parallel, such as [[resistors]]; whether these be in the electrical, thermal, hydraulic, or mechanical domains. A similar expression appears in the transversal vibrations of beams for the elastic moduli.<ref>Experimental study of the Timoshenko beam theory predictions, A.Díaz-de-Anda J.Flores, L.Gutiérrez, R.A.Méndez-Sánchez, G.Monsivais, and A.Morales.Journal of Sound and Vibration Volume 331, Issue 26, 17 December 2012, Pages 5732-5744 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jsv.2012.07.041</ref> This relationship is determined by the physical properties of the elements as well as the [[continuity equation]] linking them.
==See also==
*[[Center-of-momentum frame]] *[[Momentum conservation]] *[[Defining equation (physics)]] *[[Harmonic oscillator]] *[[Chirp mass]], a relativistic equivalent used in the [[post-Newtonian expansion]]
==References==

revision.text:
'''Robert John Hanson''' (May 25, 1920 – October 1, 2005) served on board the [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress|B-17]] [[Bomber|bomber aircraft]] the [[Memphis Belle (aircraft)|''Memphis Belle'']] during the [[World War II|Second World War]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1500841/Robert-Hanson.html|title=Robert Hanson|date=2005-10-17|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
{{Infobox military person | name = Robert John Hanson | birth_date = May 25, 1920 | death_date = October 1, 2005 | birth_place = Walla Walla, Washington | death_place = Albuquerque, New Mexico | allegiance = United States of America | branch = US Army; US Army Airforce | rank = Technician Sergeant | battles = Second World War | awards = US Distinguished Flying Cross; Air Medal (Three Oak Leaf Clusters) | laterwork = Company District Manager }}
== Early life == Robert Hanson was born in [[Walla Walla, Washington|Walla Walla]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/robert-hanson-1-1099926|title=Robert Hanson|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en}}</ref> state on May 25, 1920.<ref name=":0" />
He and his two brothers were placed in an [[orphanage]] following the death of his mother when he was young. His father was a road builder and regularly absent. An uncle took them out of the orphanage and raised them at [[Garfield, Washington|Garfield]], Washington. While there, Robert was a star at athletics at high school.<ref name=":0" />
His sporting prowess saw him win a [[baseball]] [[scholarship]] to university.<ref name=":0" /> However, Robert opted to go straight into work and became a [[construction worker]] in [[Spokane, Washington|Spokane]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/oct/10/local/me-hanson10|title=Robert Hanson, 85; Last Living Crewman of the Memphis Belle|last=Oliver|first=Myrna|date=2005-10-10|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> From there Robert enlisted in the [[United States Army|US Army]] in the summer of 1941.<ref name=":0" /> However, he determined not to become an [[infantry]]man after the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|Japanese attack on Pearl Harbour]] and volunteered for radio training which saw his transfer to the [[United States Army Air Forces|US Army Air Forces]].<ref name=":0" />
When training at Walla Walla, he was assigned to the ''Memphis Belle''.<ref name=":1" />
== ''Memphis Belle'' == [[File:Memphis Belle crew.jpg|thumb|310x310px|The "Memphis Belle" crew shown at an air base in England after completing 25 missions over enemy territory on June 7, 1943. Left to right: Tech. Sgt. Harold P. Loch, top turret gunner; Staff Sgt. Cecil H. Scott, ball turret gunner; '''Tech. Sgt. Robert J, Hanson''', radio operator; Capt. James A. Verinis, co-pilot; Capt. Robert K. Morgan, pilot; Capt. Charles B. Leighton, navigator; Staff Sgt. John P. Quinlan, tail gunner; Staff Sgt. Casimer A. Nastal, waist gunner; Capt. Vincent B. Evans, bombardier and Staff Sgt. Clarence E. Wichell, waist gunner.]] The crew flew the ''Memphis Belle'' to their wartime base in the [[United Kingdom]] in September 1942. From there they flew against targets in [[France]] and [[Nazi Germany]] between November 7, 1942, and May 17, 1943. The air raids amounted to 148 hours of flying and over 60 tonnes of bombs dropped.<ref name=":1" />
The first raid on November 7 was against the dockyard at [[Brest, France|Brest]] in France. The crew's other missions came approximately every 10 days attacking the ports of France, [[Belgium]] and Nazi Germany.<ref name=":0" />
Hanson carried a [[Rabbit's foot|lucky rabbit's foot]] on their missions.<ref name=":0" />
The crew had some close shaves: on one occasion the tail of the aircraft was shot away. This happened on January 23, 1943, while attacking the [[submarine pen]]s at [[Lorient]] in France.<ref name=":0" /> As Hanson related -<ref name=":1" /> {{Quote|text="When we got the tail shot off, Capt. Morgan put the ship into a terrific dive and we dropped two- or three-thousand feet. It pretty nearly threw me out of the airplane,
"I hit the roof. I thought we were going down and wondered if I should bail out. Then he pulled up again and I landed on my back. I had an ammunition box and a frequency meter on top of me. I didn't know what was going on."|sign=Robert Hanson|source=LA Times (3)}} The ''Memphis Belle'' made it back to base with 68 rips in the fabric of the [[fuselage]].<ref name=":0" />
On another occasion Hanson sneezed while writing in his [[logbook]]. At that moment a bullet passed through the space previously occupied by his head, striking his logbook. He kept the book for the rest of his life.<ref name=":1" />
The first aircraft to complete at tour of 25 missions was the [[Hot Stuff (aircraft)|Hot Stuff]], a [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator|B-24 Liberator]] bomber. However, it crashed into a mountain en route to the United States in bad weather. The ''Memphis Belle'' was selected to return to the United States in its place upon completing their 25-mission tour.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanairmuseum.com/aircraft/149|title=41-23728 {{!}} American Air Museum in Britain|website=www.americanairmuseum.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref>
After finishing their tour the crew were introduced to [[George VI|King George VI]] and [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother|Queen Elizabeth]]. They then returned to the United States to take part in a 32-city tour to raise morale and sell war bonds. They were accompanied on the tour by their [[Terrier|Highland Terrier]] mascot called Stuka.<ref name=":0" />
Their arrival back in the United States took place at Long Beach on August 19, 1943, to the cheers of thousands [[Douglas Aircraft Company]] workers.<ref name=":1" />
== Later life == For the remainder of his life, Hanson used his wartime [[Morse code|Morse Code]] sign-off of "dit, dit, dit, dah, dit, dah" to end telephone calls.<ref name=":1" />
After his wartime service Hanson returned to Washington state. He worked for Nalley Fine Foods in Walla Walla as a salesman and subsequently a regional manager. He also worked for a Spokane candy company. Upon retirement he moved to [[Mesa, Arizona|Mesa]], [[Arizona]], and later [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]] in [[New Mexico]].<ref name=":1" />
== Personal life == In 1942 Hanson married Irene Payton, who survived him along with their son and daughter. However, he was predeceased by another daughter.<ref name=":0" />
== In popular culture == Hanson appears in the 1944 documentary '[[Memphis Belle: A Story of a Flying Fortress|The Memphis Belle: A Story of a Flying Fortress]]' directed by [[William Wyler]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Wyler|first=William|title=The Memphis Belle: A Story of a Flying Fortress|date=1944-04-13|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0036152/|others=Stanley Wray, Robert Morgan, James A. Verinis|accessdate=2018-05-29}}</ref>
There was also a 1990 film '[[Memphis Belle (film)|Memphis Belle]]' directed by [[Michael Caton-Jones]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Caton-Jones|first=Michael|title=Memphis Belle|date=1990-10-12|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100133/|others=Matthew Modine, Eric Stoltz, Tate Donovan|accessdate=2018-05-29}}</ref>
During the 1989 production Hanson visited the cast during filming at [[RAF Binbrook]] in the United Kingdom. Hanson joked, "They're not quite as good-looking as we were ... but they are young and enthusiastic – exactly like we were".<ref name=":1" />
After the release of the film Hanson spoke to his grandson's high school class. When asked if what happened in the film was true, he replied "No, it didn't all happen to the ''Memphis Belle'', but everything in the movie happened to some B-17".<ref name=":1" />

{{short description|North American desert}} {{Infobox valley | name = Sonoran Desert | other_name = | photo = Saguaro National Park - Flickr - Joe Parks.jpg | photo_caption = [[Saguaro National Park]], [[Arizona]] | map = | map_image = Sonoran Desert map.svg | map_caption = Sonoran Desert | location = | country = United States | country1 = Mexico | state = [[Arizona]] | state1 = [[California]] | state2 = [[Sonora]] | state3 = [[Sinaloa]] | state4 = [[Baja California (state)|Baja California]] | relief = | label = | label_position = | coordinates = {{coord}} | coordinates_ref = | elevation = | elevation_m = | elevation_ft = | elevation_ref = | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | length_orientation = | length_note = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | width_orientation = | width_note = | area = | area_mi2 = | area_km2 = | depth = | depth_ft = | depth_m = | type = | age = | border = [[Mojave Desert]] (north)
[[Colorado Plateau]] (north and east)
[[Peninsular Ranges]] (west) | topo = | traversed = | river = | footnotes = | embed = }} The '''Sonoran Desert''' is a [[North American deserts|North American desert]] which covers large parts of the [[Southwestern United States]] in [[Arizona]] and [[California]] and of Northwestern Mexico in [[Sonora]], [[Baja California (state)|Baja California]], and [[Baja California Sur]]. It is the hottest desert in Mexico. It has an area of {{convert|260000|km2|sqmi|sp=us}}. The western portion of the [[United States–Mexico border]] passes through the Sonoran Desert. In [[phytogeography]], the Sonoran Desert is within the Sonoran [[Floristic province|Floristic Province]] of the [[Madrean Region]] in southwestern North America, part of the [[Holarctic|Holarctic Kingdom]] of the northern [[Western Hemisphere]]. The desert contains a variety of unique and [[endemism|endemic]] [[plant]]s and [[animal]]s, such as the [[saguaro]] (''Carnegiea gigantea'') and [[Stenocereus thurberi|organ pipe cactus]] (''Stenocereus thurberi''). ==Location== The Sonoran desert wraps around the northern end of the [[Gulf of California]], from [[Baja California Sur]] ([[El Vizcaíno Biosphere Reserve]] in central and Pacific west coast, Central Gulf Coast subregion on east to southern tip), north through much of [[Baja California (state)|Baja California]], excluding the central northwest mountains and Pacific west coast, through southeastern California and southwestern and southern Arizona to western and central parts of [[Sonora]].{{cite web|url=http://www.desertmuseum.org/|title=Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum, Tucson, AZ - Zoo, Botanical Garden and Art Gallery|author=|date=|website=www.desertmuseum.org|accessdate=15 April 2018}} It is bounded on the west by the [[Peninsular Ranges]], which separate it from the [[California chaparral and woodlands]] (northwest) and [[Baja California Desert]] (Vizcaino subregion, central and southeast) ecoregions of the Pacific slope. To the north in California and northwest Arizona, the Sonoran Desert transitions to the colder-winter, higher-elevation [[Mojave Desert|Mojave]], [[Great Basin]], and [[Colorado Plateau]] deserts. To the east and southeast, the deserts transition to the [[Temperate coniferous forests|coniferous]] [[Arizona Mountains forests]] and [[Sierra Madre Occidental|Sierra Madre]] and [[Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests|Sierra Madre Occidental pine–oak forests]] at higher elevations. To the south the [[Sonoran-Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest|Sonoran–Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest]] is the transition zone from the Sonoran Desert to the tropical dry forests of the Mexican state of [[Sinaloa]]. ==Sub-region deserts== The desert's sub-regions include the [[Colorado Desert]] of southeastern California; and the [[Yuma Desert]] east of the north-to-south section of the [[Colorado River]] in southwest Arizona. In the 1957 publication, ''Vegetation of the Sonoran Desert'', Forrest Shreve divided the Sonoran Desert into seven regions according to characteristic vegetation: Lower Colorado Valley, Arizona Upland, Plains of Sonora, Foothills of Sonora, Central Gulf Coast, Vizcaíno Region, and Magdalena Region.{{cite web|url=http://alic.arid.arizona.edu/sonoran/documents/mcginnies/McGinnies_overview.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030121161839/http://alic.arid.arizona.edu/sonoran/documents/mcginnies/McGinnies_overview.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 January 2003|title=Sonoran Desert: An Overview of the Sonoran Desert by William G. McGinnies|author=|date=21 January 2003|accessdate=15 April 2018}} Many ecologists now consider Shreve's Vizcaíno and Magdalena regions, which lie on the western side of the [[Baja California Peninsula]], to be a separate [[ecoregion]], the [[Baja California Desert]]. Within the southern Sonoran Desert in Mexico is found the [[Gran Desierto de Altar]], with the ''[[Pinacate Peaks|Reserva de la Biosfera el Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar]]'' ('Pinacate National Park' in Mexico), extending {{convert|2000|km2|sqmi|sp=us}} of desert and mountainous regions.http://www.bajaquest.com/penasco/pinacate.htm The Pinacate National Park includes the only active [[Erg (landform)|Erg]] dune region in North America. The nearest city to the ''Reserva de la Biosfera el Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar'' is [[Puerto Peñasco]] (a.k.a. 'Rocky Point') in the state of [[Sonora]], [[Mexico]]. ;Sub-regions Sonoran Desert sub-regions include: *[[Colorado Desert]] *[[Gran Desierto de Altar]] *[[Lechuguilla Desert]] *[[Tonopah Desert]] *[[Yuha Desert]] *[[Yuma Desert]] ==Ecology== The Sonoran Desert includes 60 mammal species, 350 bird species, 20 amphibian species, over 100 reptile species, 30 native fish species, over 1000 native bee species, and more than 2,000 native plant species.[http://nationalzoo.si.edu/Publications/ZooGoer/2005/1/survivingsonoran.cfm Surviving the Sonoran] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430061202/http://nationalzoo.si.edu/Publications/ZooGoer/2005/1/survivingsonoran.cfm |date=2010-04-30 }} The Sonoran Desert area southeast of [[Tucson]] and near the Mexican border is vital habitat for the only population of [[jaguar]]s living within the United States.[http://www.envsci.nau.edu/scbs/students/2004_newell/Jaguar%20web%20site/conservation.html The Jaguar in the Borderlands of Arizona, New Mexico and Northern Mexico: Conservation—Threats & Strategies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330143949/http://www.envsci.nau.edu/scbs/students/2004_newell/Jaguar%20web%20site/conservation.html |date=2009-03-30 }} The [[Colorado River Delta]] was once an ecological hotspot within the Sonoran desert, fueled by the flow of fresh water through the Colorado river in this otherwise dry area, but the delta has been greatly reduced in extent due to the damming and use of the river upstream. ===Flora=== {{See|Flora of the Sonoran Desert}} {{main|:Category:Flora of the Sonoran Deserts}} {{see also|List of flora of the Sonoran Desert Region by common name}} [[Image:Sonoradesert 1.JPG|200px|thumb|The Sonoran Desert near [[Tucson, Arizona]] during winter.]] Many plants not only survive, but thrive in the harsh conditions of the Sonoran Desert. Many have evolved to have specialized adaptations to the desert climate. The Sonoran Desert's biseasonal rainfall pattern results in more plant species than any other desert in the world.{{WWF ecoregion|name=Sonoran desert|id=na1310}} The Sonoran Desert includes plant genera and species from the [[agave]] family, [[Arecaceae|palm]] family, [[cactus]] family, [[legume]] family, and numerous others. The Sonoran is the only place in the world where the famous [[saguaro cactus]] (''Carnegiea gigantea'') grows in the wild.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/sagu/planyourvisit/upload/Saguaro-Brochure.pdf|title=The Saguaro Cactus|author=|date=|website=nps.gov|accessdate=15 April 2018}} [[Cylindropuntia|Cholla]] (''Cylindropuntia'' spp.), [[Opuntia basilaris|beavertail]] (''Opuntia basilaris''), [[Echinocereus|hedgehog]] (''Echinocereus'' spp.), [[Ferocactus wislizeni|fishhook]] (''Ferocactus wislizeni''), [[Opuntia|prickly pear]] (''Opuntia'' spp.), [[Peniocereus|nightblooming cereus]] (''Peniocereus'' spp.), and [[Stenocereus thurberi|organ pipe]] (''Stenocereus thurberi'') are other taxa of cacti found here. Cactus provides food and homes to many desert mammals and birds, with showy flowers in reds, pinks, yellows, and whites, blooming most commonly from late March through June, depending on the species and seasonal temperatures. [[Larrea tridentata|Creosote bush]] (''Larrea tridentata'') and [[Ambrosia dumosa|bur sage]] (''Ambrosia dumosa'') dominate valley floors. [[Psorothamnus fremontii|Indigo bush]] (''Psorothamnus fremontii'') and [[Mormon tea]] are other shrubs that may be found. [[List of Sonoran Desert wildflowers|Wildflowers of the Sonoran Desert]] include [[Abronia villosa|desert sand verbena]] (''Abronia villosa''), [[Geraea canescens|desert sunflower]] (''Geraea canescens''), and [[evening primrose]]s. [[File:Prosopis velutina Anza-Borrego.jpg|thumb|[[Prosopis velutina|Velvet mesquite]] (''Prosopis velutina'')]] Ascending from the valley up [[Bajada (geography)|bajada]]s, various subtrees such as [[Prosopis velutina|velvet mesquite]] (''Prosopis velutina''), [[Parkinsonia florida|palo verde]] (''Parkinsonia florida''), [[Olneya tesota|desert ironwood]] (''Olneya tesota''), [[Chilopsis linearis|desert willow]] (''Chilopsis linearis'' ssp. ''arcuata''), and [[Canotia holacantha|crucifixion thorn]] (''Canotia holacantha'') are common, as well as multi-stemmed [[Fouquieria splendens|ocotillo]] (''Fouquieria splendens''). Shrubs found at higher elevations include [[Acacia constricta|whitethorn acacia]] (''Acacia constricta''), fairy duster, and [[jojoba]]. In the desert subdivisions found on Baja California, cardon cactus, elephant tree, and [[boojum tree]] occur.MacMahon, J. A. ''Deserts''. 1986, 638 pages [[File:Washingtonia filifera Anza-Borrego.jpg|thumb|''[[Washingtonia filifera]]'' in [[Anza Borrego Desert State Park]]]] The [[Washingtonia filifera|California fan palm]] (''Washingtonia filifera'') is found in the [[Colorado Desert]] section of the Sonoran Desert, the only [[native plant|native]] palm in California, among many other introduced [[Arecaceae]] genera and species. It is found at [[spring (hydrosphere)|spring]]-fed [[oasis|oases]], such as in [[Anza Borrego Desert State Park]], [[Joshua Tree National Park]], and the [[Kofa National Wildlife Refuge]].Hogan, C. M. 2009. [http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=90942 California Fan Palm: ''Washingtonia filifera'', GlobalTwitcher.com, ed. N. Stromberg] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930184850/http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=90942 |date=2009-09-30 }} ===Fauna=== {{main|:Category:Fauna of the Sonoran Desert}} {{see also|List of Sonoran Desert birds (Arizona)}} ==Human population== {{main|:Category:History of indigenous peoples of North America}} {{see also|:Category:Native American history of California}} The Sonoran Desert is home to the cultures of over{{how many?|date=October 2017}} seventeen contemporary [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] tribes, with settlements at [[:Category:American Indian reservations in California|American Indian reservations in California]] and [[:Category:American Indian reservations in Arizona|Arizona]], as well as populations in Mexico. The largest city in the Sonoran Desert is [[Phoenix, Arizona]], with a 2013 metropolitan population of about 4.3 million.[https://www.census.gov/population/www/estimates/metro_general/2006/CBSA-EST2006-01.csv Table 1: Annual Estimates of the Population of Metropolitan and Micropolitan Statistical Areas: April 1, 2000 to July 1, 2006 (CBSA-EST2006-01)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5QE4IXsae?url=http://www.census.gov/population/www/estimates/metro_general/2006/CBSA-EST2006-01.csv |date=July 10, 2007 }}, [[United States Census Bureau]], 2007-04-05. Accessed 2007-09-11{{Failed verification|date=March 2014}} Located on the [[Salt River (Arizona)|Salt River]] in central Arizona, it is one of the fastest-growing [[United States metropolitan area|metropolitan areas]] in the United States. In 2007 in the Phoenix area, desert was losing ground to [[urban sprawl]] at a rate of approximately {{convert|4000|m2|acre|0|sp=us}} per hour.[http://researchmag.asu.edu/stories/ewan.html Make No Small Plans], Adelheid Fischer, ''ASU Research'' magazine. Accessed on line October 15, 2007 The next largest cities are [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]], in southern Arizona, with a metro area population of around 1 million, and [[Mexicali]], [[Baja California]], whose [[Municipalities of Mexico|municipality]] also has a population of around 900,000. The municipality of [[Hermosillo]], [[Sonora]], has a population of around 700,000. [[Ciudad Obregón]], [[Sonora]], in the southern part of the desert, has a population of 375,800.[http://www.inegi.gob.mx/est/contenidos/espanol/sistemas/conteo2005/localidad/iter/ Principales resultados por localidad 2005] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070316010215/http://www.inegi.gob.mx/est/contenidos/espanol/sistemas/conteo2005/localidad/iter/ |date=2007-03-16 }}, Instituto Nacional de Estadística Geografía e Informática (Mexico). Accessed on line October 15, 2007[http://www.bajacalifornia.gob.mx/english/Our_State/proyecciones.jsp Population Projections] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222041121/http://www.bajacalifornia.gob.mx/english/Our_State/proyecciones.jsp |date=2007-12-22 }}, state government of Baja California, Mexico. Accessed on line October 15, 2007 ===California=== The [[Coachella Valley]], located in the [[Colorado Desert]] section of the Sonoran Desert, has a population of 365,000. Many famous [[Southern California]] desert resort cities such as [[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs]] and [[Palm Desert, California|Palm Desert]] are located here. [[File:Gateway to the Springs.jpg|thumb|left|The entrance to [[Palm Springs, California]] via [[Highway 62]]]] During the winter months, from November to April, the daytime temperatures in the Coachella Valley range from 70 °F (21 °C) to 90 °F (32 °C) and corresponding nighttime lows range from 46 °F (8 °C) to 68 °F (20 °C) making it a popular winter resort destination. Due to its warm year-round climate [[citrus]] and subtropical fruits such as mangoes, figs, and dates are grown in the Coachella Valley and adjacent [[Imperial Valley]]. Imperial Valley has a total population of about 188,000 and has a similar climate to that of the Coachella Valley. Other cities include [[Indio, California|Indio]], [[Coachella, California|Coachella]], [[Calexico, California|Calexico]], [[El Centro, California|El Centro,]] [[Imperial, California|Imperial]], [[Palm Desert, California|Palm Desert]] and [[Blythe, California|Blythe]]. ===Undocumented border crossing=== Straddling as it does the [[Mexico–United States border|US-Mexican border]], with low levels of human-installed security, the Sonoran desert is a popular route to attempt unauthorized entry across the border. The harsh conditions mean that the 3-5-day march, usually moving at night to minimize exposure to the heat, often ends in death.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21029783 Arizona: Naming the dead from the desert], BBC News, 17 January 2013 ==Parks, conservation centers and research facilities== [[File:Sondes.jpg|200px|thumb|[[Mexican Gold Poppy|Mexican goldpoppies]] in the [[Sonoran Desert National Monument]]]] There are many National Parks and Monuments; federal and state [[nature reserve]]s and [[wildlife refuge]]s; state, county, and city parks; and government or nonprofit group operated [[natural history museum]]s, science research institutes, and [[botanical garden]]s and desert landscape [[garden]]s. *[[:Category:Protected areas of the Sonoran Desert|Index: Protected areas of the Sonoran Desert]] *[[:Category:Protected areas of the Colorado Desert|Index: Protected areas of the Colorado Desert]] ;Sonoran Desert protected areas include: {{Div col}} *[[Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum|Arizona–Sonora Desert Museum]] *[[Sonoran Desert National Monument]] The [[Sonoran Desert National Monument]] was created in 2001 in Arizona, to enhance protection of the unique resources of the Sonoran Desert, with {{convert|2008|km2|acre|sp=us}}.

Accessed on line June 17, 2009. *[[Boyce Thompson Arboretum State Park]]—''Sonoran Desert flora arboretum'' *[[Anza-Borrego Desert State Park|Anza–Borrego Desert State Park]] *[[Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument]] *[[Saguaro National Park]] *[[Joshua Tree National Park]] *[[Pinacate Peaks|Reserva de la Biosfera el Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar]]—''Pinacate National Park, in Sonora, Mexico'' *[[Indio Hills Palms|Indio Hills Palms State Reserve]] *[[Coachella Valley National Wildlife Refuge]] *[[Cabeza Prieta National Wildlife Refuge]] *[[Kofa National Wildlife Refuge]] *[[South Mountain Park]] *[[Sonoran Arthropod Studies Institute]] {{div col end}} ==Gallery== Sonoran Desert 33.081359 n112.431507.JPG|Sonoran Desert near [[Maricopa, Arizona]] File:Sonora desert of altar.jpg|Sand dunes in the Gran Desierto de Altar File:sonoran desert mountains.jpg|The [[Santa Catalina Mountains]] in the Sonoran Desert near [[Tucson, Arizona]] File:El Camino del Diablo, border patrol.jpg|A [[US Border Patrol]] helicopter along [[El Camino Del Diablo]], a historic 250-mile trail in the Sonoran Desert File:20091211 - revision.text:
{{short description|A band of low-level convergence, cloudiness and precipitation extending from the Western Pacific Warm Pool at the maritime continent south-eastwards towards French Polynesia and as far as the Cook Islands}} The '''South Pacific Convergence Zone''' (SPCZ), a reverse-oriented [[monsoon trough]], is a band of low-level convergence, cloudiness and precipitation extending from the [[Western Pacific Warm Pool]] at the maritime continent south-eastwards towards French Polynesia and as far as the [[Cook Islands]] (160W, 20S). The SPCZ is a portion of the [[Intertropical Convergence Zone]] (ITCZ) which lies in a band extending east-west near the Equator but can be more extratropical in nature, especially east of the [[International Date Line]]. It is considered the largest and most important piece of the ITCZ, and has the least dependence upon heating from a nearby landmass during the summer than any other portion of the [[monsoon trough]].<ref>E. Linacre and B. Geerts. [http://www-das.uwyo.edu/~geerts/cwx/notes/chap12/spcz.html Movement of the South Pacific Convergence Zone.] Retrieved on 2006-11-26.</ref> The SPCZ can affect the precipitation on Polynesian islands in the southwest Pacific Ocean, so it is important to understand how the SPCZ behaves with large-scale, global climate phenomenon, such as the ITCZ, [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation]], and the [[Interdecadal Pacific oscillation]] (IPO), a portion of the [[Pacific decadal oscillation]].
==Position== [[File:Folland2002 figure1.png|thumbnail|right|Figure 1 of Folland et al. (2002) shows the mean position of the SPCZ based on four different measurements: maximum rainfall, maximum of low level [[Cloud|convergence]], maxima of the 500 hPa vertical motion, and the minimum in [[outgoing longwave radiation]] (OLR)]]
The SPCZ occurs where the southeast trades from transitory [[anticyclone]]s to the south meet with the semipermanent easterly flow from the eastern South Pacific anticyclone. The SPCZ exists in summer and winter but can change its orientation and location. It is often distinct from the ITCZ over Australia, but at times they become one continuous zone of convergence. The location of the SPCZ is affected by [[El Niño|ENSO]] and [[Interdecadal Pacific oscillation]] conditions. It generally stretches from the [[Solomon Islands]] through [[Vanuatu]], [[Fiji]], [[Samoa]], and [[Tonga]]. Low-level convergence along this band forms cloudiness as well as showers and [[thunderstorm]]s.<ref>Glossary of Meteorology. [http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=south-pacific-convergence-zone1 South Pacific convergence zone.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930210848/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=south-pacific-convergence-zone1 |date=2007-09-30 }} Retrieved on 2006-11-26.</ref> Thunderstorm activity, or convection, within the band is dependent upon the season, as the more equatorward portion is most active in the Southern Hemisphere summer, and the more poleward portion is most active during transition seasons of [[fall]] and spring.<ref>Stephen B. Cocks. [https://txspace.tamu.edu/bitstream/1969.1/374/1/etd-tamu-2003C-ATMO-Cocks-1.pdf An Observational Study of the South Pacific Convergence Zone Using Satellite and Model Re-Analysis Data.]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Retrieved on 2006-11-26.</ref> The convergence zone shifts east or west depending on the existence of El Niño, or the phase of [[ENSO]].
===Measuring SPCZ position=== The climatological position can be estimated by computing its mean position over 30 or more years.<ref name="Folland">{{cite journal | author=C. K. Folland, J. A. Renwick, [[Jim Salinger|M. J. Salinger]], A. B. Mullan | title=Relative influences of the Interdecadal Pacific Oscillation and ENSO in the South Pacific Convergence Zone | journal=Geophysical Research Letters | volume=29 | issue=13 | year=2002 | pages=21–1–21–4|doi=10.1029/2001GL014201 | bibcode=2002GeoRL..29.1643F}}</ref> There are several metrics to measure the position of the SPCZ. The location of maximum rainfall, maximum of low level [[Cloud|convergence]], maxima of the 500 hPa vertical motion, and the minimum in [[outgoing longwave radiation]] (OLR) are four indicators of the SPCZ axis.<ref name="Folland" /> Figure 1 shows qualitative agreement between all of these SPCZ indicators.
==Changes in SPCZ position== The position of the SPCZ can change on seasonal, interannual, and possibly longer timescales.
===Observations=== Research into SPCZ movements of the 20th century are linked to changes in the IPO and ENSO.<ref name=Folland /> Folland et al., 2002 defined an index to describe the [[Interdecadal Pacific oscillation]] (IPO) with sea surface temperature and night marine air temperature to determine how the SPCZ varies with the IPO. When the IPO index has negative temperature anomalies, the SPCZ is displaced southwest and moves northeastward when the IPO index has positive temperature anomalies. The [[Southern Oscillation Index]] (SOI) is a metric for describing warm- and cold-phase conditions associated with the [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation]] (ENSO) and can also describe movements of the position of the SPCZ. Negative SOI index values are associated with warm-phase or El Niño-like conditions and a northeastward displacement of the SPCZ. Positive SOI index values, on the other hand, describe cold-phase or La Niña-like conditions and a southwestward displacement of the SPCZ.<ref name="Folland" />
Determining the position of the SPCZ over longer timescales in the past (pre-20th century) has been studied using coral records of the southwest Pacific.<ref name="Linsley">Braddock K. Linsley, Alexey Kaplan, Yves Gouriou, [[Jim Salinger]], Peter B. deMenocal, Gerard M. Wellington, and Stephen S. Howe. [http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/2006/2005GC001115.shtml Tracking the extent of the South Pacific Convergence Zone since the early 1600s.] Retrieved on 2006-11-26.</ref> Linsley et al. (2006) reconstructed sea-surface temperature and sea surface salinity in the southwest Pacific starting circa 1600CE by measuring the oxygen isotopic composition of four [[Porites]] coral records from [[Rarotonga]] and two from [[Fiji]]. Coral isotope measurements provide information on both sea surface temperature and sea surface salinity, so they can indicate times of increased or decreased temperature and/or precipitation associated with changes in the position of the SPCZ. Their coral oxygen isotope index indicated an eastward shift of the decadal mean position of the SPCZ since the mid 1800s. A shift of the SPCZ in this direction suggests there were more La Niña-like or cold-phase conditions in the Pacific, during this period, often called the [[Little Ice Age]].<ref name="Linsley" /> Additional paleoclimate studies are still needed in order to test the reliability of these coral results.
The IPO and ENSO can interact together to produce changes in the position of the SPCZ. West of about 140 W, both ENSO (measured with [[Southern Oscillation Index]]) and IPO strongly influence the SPCZ latitude, but farther east only ENSO is a significant factor. Only near 170 W is there any indication of an interaction between the two factors.<ref name="Folland" />
===Climate modelling=== Besides observations of the SPCZ and movement in its position, there have been modelling studies as well.<ref name="Widlanksy">Matthew J. Widlansky, Axel Timmermann, Karl Stein, Shayne McGregor, Niklas Schneider, Matthew H. England, Matthieu Lengaigne, and Wenju Cai. [http://www.nature.com/nclimate/journal/v3/n4/full/nclimate1726.html Changes in South Pacific rainfall bands in a warming climate]</ref> Widlansky et al. (2012) used a number of [[climate models]] of differing complexity to simulate rainfall bands in the southwest Pacific and see how the magnitude and areal extent was affected by the SPCZ and [[ENSO]]. During El Niño or warm-phase conditions, the SPCZ typically shifted northeastward with dryer conditions on islands to the southwest, in agreement with observations. Conversely, a southwestward shift in rainfall accompanied La Niña or cold-phase events in the simulations. Widlanksy et al. (2012) argued the sea surface temperature biases in models created uncertainty in the rainfall projections and produce what has been named “the double ITCZ problem”. The impact of sea surface temperature bias was further investigated by using uncoupled atmospheric models with prescribed sea surface temperatures, and those 3 models each with differing complexity showed less severe double ITCZ bias than the ensemble of coupled models.<ref name="Widlanksy" />
==Related oceanography== [[File:Linsley2006 figure1.png|thumbnail|right|Figure 1 of Linsley et al. (2006) shows the annual average precipitation in the top panel and the annual average salinity in the bottom panel. Warmer colors indicate increased precipitation or salinity while colder colors indicate decreased precipitation or salinity. The salinity front, a function of SPCZ position, is labeled in the bottom panel.]]
At its southeast edge, the circulation around the feature forces a salinity gradient in the ocean, with fresher and warmer waters of the western Pacific lying to its west. Cooler and saltier waters lie to its east.<ref name="Linsley" />
==See also== *[[El Niño–Southern Oscillation]] *[[Monsoon trough]] *[[Tropical cyclogenesis]] *[[Tropical cyclone]] *[[Coral bleaching]]

[[File:28June2012.jpg|thumbnail|right|Satellite view 28 June 2012 showing low to west of Europe]] The '''Spanish Plume''' (Penacho Ibérico in Spanish and Spaanse Pluim in Dutch) is a weather pattern in which a [[Plume (hydrodynamics)|plume]] of warm air moves from the [[Iberia]]n plateau or the [[Sahara]] to [[northwest Europe]] giving rise to severe thunderstorms. This meteorological pattern can lead to [[Heat wave|extreme high temperatures]] and intense rainfall during the summer months, with potential for [[flash flood]]ing, damaging [[hail]] storms and [[tornado]] formation. Some of these intense thunderstorm are formed from [[Thermal low|thermal lows]]. Thermal lows is also known as [[Thermal low|heat lows]]. Thermal lows can be semi permanent feature around some parts of the Europe particularly in the summer season. These thermal lows can be developed or created around Spain, Portugal, France etc. during the summer season because of the intense heat. Thermal low pressure can be located around the world particularly in the summer or tropical regions.
==Notable occurrences== * 1788, 13 July, a [[hailstorm]] sweeps across France and the [[Dutch Republic]] with hailstones 'as big as quart bottles' that take 'three days to melt'; immense damage is done.<ref>{{cite book|title=Agricultural Records|last=Stratton|first=J. M.|publisher=John Baker|location=London|year=1969|isbn=0-212-97022-4}}</ref> * 1896, 10 September Paris Tornado.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mahieu|first1=Pierre|last2=Wesolek|first2=Emmanuel|title=CONSEQUENCES OF TORNADIC STORMS IN URBAN AREAS:CASE STUDY OF THE PARIS TORNADO (FRANCE) IN SEPTEMBER 10,1896|journal=6th European Conference on Severe Storms. 2011|date=26 August 2011|url=http://www.keraunos.org/recherche-consequences-of-tornadic-storms-in-urban-areas.pdf|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref> * 1897, 24 July saw thunderstorms disrupt the celebrations of Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Webb|first1=Jonathan D. C.|title=Severe thunderstorms disrupt the Diamond Jubilee on Midsummer Day 1897|journal=Weather|date=2012|volume=67|issue=7|pages=174–175|doi=10.1002/wea.1959|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/wea.1959/abstract?deniedAccessCustomisedMessage=&userIsAuthenticated=false|accessdate=18 July 2014|bibcode=2012Wthr...67..174W}}</ref> * 1955, 18 July a Spanish Plume brought a record amount of rain on one day to [[Winterborne St Martin|Martinstown]] Dorset, with slow-moving thunderstorms bringing 279mm of rainfall.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lee|first=John|title=Extreme weather in the UK|url=http://www.weathercast.co.uk/weather-news/news/ch/a925c0f6c2c5359ac8329fae13b32166/article/extreme_weather_in_the_uk.html|accessdate=12 August 2013|newspaper=Meteogroup:Weathercast|date=10 August 2013}}</ref> A record which stood for over 50 years until the [[2009 Great Britain and Ireland floods|2009 Cumbria floods]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Wild weather: Dorset's 1955 'record rainfall'?|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/dorset/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8994000/8994478.stm|accessdate=12 August 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=10 September 2010}}</ref> * 1958, 5 September [[Horsham]] storm, heaviest hailstone recorded in the UK (190g).<ref name="Carlson" >{{cite journal|last=Carlson|first=T. N.|author2=Ludlam, F. H. |title=Conditions for the occurrence of severe local storms|journal=Tellus|year=1968|volume=XX|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:-BJTYTnnc14J:tellusa.net/index.php/tellusa/article/download/10002/11618+Conditions+for+the+occurrence+of+severe+local+storms+(Citations:+31)+T.+N.+CARLSON,+F.+H.+LUDLAM&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESg4Mp__HVbXVvfnTbEO7QBwkbrmpq0JruewCwugZF8-oIShFTL4ak4EKTtTgp0pCewXeQONGl-gPELdrwPYbPCZV8a490bM_U0hAt-skPGggfUDHx5LuadsYLvvluLFmfP-oyUH&sig=AHIEtbTAEP4xPJiMrVY4RgTzCiWdnSBgug|accessdate=5 November 2012|doi=10.1111/j.2153-3490.1968.tb00364.x|pages=203–226}}</ref> * 1959, 9 July [[Wokingham]] storm.<ref name="Carlson" /> the first in the world to be identified as a [[supercell]].<ref name="Browning">{{cite journal |last = Browning |first = K.A. |authorlink = Keith Browning |author2 = F.H. Ludlum |title = Airflow in Convective Storms |journal = Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society |volume = 88 |issue = 376 |pages = 117–35 |date = Apr 1962 |url = http://www.rmets.org/pdf/qj62browning.pdf |doi = 10.1002/qj.49708837602 |bibcode = 1962QJRMS..88..117B |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120307213602/http://www.rmets.org/pdf/qj62browning.pdf |archivedate = 2012-03-07 |df = }}</ref> * 1961, 12 August synoptic set-up of a Spanish Plume, however dry ground conditions in France led to little evaporation which led to lack of moisture in the air to fuel cloud and storm formation.<ref name="Carlson" /> * 1968, 2 July [[July 1968 England and Wales dust fall storms]] – the plume had the highest [[mineral dust]] content recorded for over 200 years and caused major thunderstorms and [[rain dust]] across England.<ref name="Stevenson">{{cite journal|url=https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1002/wea.780|title=The dust fall and severe storms of 1 July 1968|first=Catherine M.|last=Stevenson|year=1969|journal=Weather|doi=10.1002/wea.780|volume=66|issue=5|accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> * 1968, 10 July [[Chew Stoke flood of 1968]]<ref name="Meteogroup" >{{cite web|title=Spanish Plume|url=http://www.weathercast.co.uk/weather-news/news/ch/c21b116d849b9eb70e0f38798ec68fbd/article/spanish_plume.html|publisher=Meteogroup|accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> [[Chew Stoke]] floods and [[Pforzheim]] tornado in Germany.<ref name="Hannesen" /> * 1975, 14 July. Hailstorm in the Midlands.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Webb|first=Jonathan D. C.|title=The great summer heatwaves of 1975 and 1976 in the UK, and some violent storms|journal=International Journal of Meteorology|year=2011|volume=36|pages=255–261}}</ref><ref name="Clark">{{cite journal|last=Clark|first=Matthew R.|author2=Webb, Jonathan D. C. |title=A severe hailstorm across the English Midlands on 28 June 2012|journal=Weather|date=November 2013|volume=68|issue=11|pages=284–291|doi=10.1002/wea.2162|bibcode=2013Wthr...68..284C}}</ref> * 1983, 25–26 July. Three Mesoscale Convective Systems over West France with Severe thunderstorm, heavy rain and Hailstorm<ref>http://www.keraunos.org/orages-25-26-juillet-1983-derecho-mcs-macrorafales-charente-vienne-poitou.pdf</ref> * 1985, 26 May East Anglia.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Webb|first=J.D.C.|author2=Elsom, D.M. |author3=Reynolds, D.J. |title=Climatology of severe hailstorms in Great Britain|journal=Atmospheric Research|date=January 2001|volume=56|issue=1–4|pages=291–308|doi=10.1016/S0169-8095(00)00081-8|bibcode = 2001AtmRe..56..291W }}</ref> [[File:MyBlitzortungStrikeMap090614.png|thumbnail|right|Lightning over western Europe 9 June 2014]] * 1992, 20–21 July Severe thunderstorms over south-east England.<ref name="McCallum" >{{cite journal|last=McCallum|first=E.|author2=Waters, A. J. |title=Severe thunderstorms over south-east England, 20/21 July 1992: Satellite and radar perspective of a mesoscale convective system|journal=Weather|date=July 1993|volume=48|issue=7|doi=10.1002/j.1477-8696.1993.tb05886.x|pages=198–208|bibcode = 1993Wthr...48..198M }}</ref> *1994, 24 June, Severe storms move from northern France and across south-eastern England.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Young|first1=M. V.|title=Severe thunderstorms over south-east England on 24 June 1994: A forecasting perspective|journal=Weather|volume=50|issue=7|pages=250–256|doi=10.1002/j.1477-8696.1995.tb06121.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/j.1477-8696.1995.tb06121.x/abstract|accessdate=17 July 2014|bibcode = 1995Wthr...50..250Y }}</ref> * 1995, 9 September A tornado was generated in the [[Rhine|Rhine Valley]], Germany.<ref name="Hannesen" >{{cite journal|last=Hannesen|first=Ronald|author2=Nikolai Dotzek |author3=Hermann Gysi |author4=Klaus D. Beheng |title=Case study of a tornado in the Upper Rhine valley|journal=Meterologische Zeitschrift Berlin|year=1998|pages=163–170|url=http://tordach.org/pdf/tornado95.pdf|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> * 1996, 7 June damaging hail storms across England from Lyme Bay to the Wash.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Webb|first=Jonathan D. C.|author2=Pike, William S. |title=Thunderstorms and hail on 7 June 1996: An early season ‘Spanish plume’ event|journal=Weather|year=1998|volume=53|issue=8|pages=234–241|doi=10.1002/j.1477-8696.1998.tb06391.x|bibcode = 1998Wthr...53..234W }}</ref> * 1997, 7 June A [[Bow echo]] formed over France before passing over Belgium and the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Delden|first1=A.|title=The synoptic setting of a thundery low and associated prefrontal squall line in western Europe|journal=Meteorology and Atmospheric Physics|volume=65|issue=1–2|pages=113–131|doi=10.1007/BF01030272|bibcode = 1998MAP....65..113D }}</ref> * 2003, 5–6 August<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Holley|first1=D. M.|last2=Dorling|first2=S. R.|last3=Steele|first3=C. J.|last4=Earl|first4=N.|title=A climatology of convective available potential energy in Great Britain|journal=International Journal of Climatology|date=November 2014|volume=34|issue=14|pages=3811–3824|doi=10.1002/joc.3976|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/joc.3976/full|accessdate=7 March 2015|bibcode = 2014IJCli..34.3811H }}</ref> * 2011, 18 August a severe storm battered the [[Pukkelpop]] festival in Belgium. This situation shows some similarities with the Spanish Plume.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pukkelpop storm, Chapter II: Description of the synoptic situation|url=http://www.eumetrain.org/data/2/274/print_2.htm|publisher=EUMeTrain|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> * 2012, 10 May high temperatures reported in south of England with a tornado in Belgium reaching 100 mph gusts in [[Ghent]].<ref name="De Standaard" >{{cite news|title=Tornado richt ravage aan|url=http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=UG3PUP46|accessdate=29 November 2012|newspaper=De Standaard|date=11 May 2012|language=Dutch}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Demeyer|first=Paul|title=Spaanse pluim richt ravage aan|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/article/detail.aspx?articleid=6I3PV8N9|accessdate=1 December 2012|newspaper=Nieuwsblad.be|date=11 May 2012|language=Dutch}}</ref> * 2012, [[2012 Great Britain and Ireland floods#28 June supercell storms|28 June supercells]] in UK and Belgium,<ref>{{cite news|title=From traffic cops to river patrol! Hosepipe bans become a distant memory as Britain has wettest spring since records began|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2166316/British-Weather-Hosepipe-bans-distant-memory-Britain-wettest-spring-records-began.html|accessdate=4 November 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=29 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Surge Bulletin|url=http://www.gabrobins.co.uk/media/13101/surge_bulletin_-_2_july_2012.pdf|publisher=GAB Robins|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702010101/http://www.gabrobins.co.uk/media/13101/surge_bulletin_-_2_july_2012.pdf|archivedate=2 July 2012|df=}}</ref> disrupted the [[2012 Summer Olympics torch relay]] and brought chaos to [[North East England]].<ref name="Clark"/><ref>{{cite news|title='Plume' blamed for freak weather|url=http://web.orange.co.uk/article/news/plume_blamed_for_freak_weather|accessdate=18 December 2012|newspaper=Orange News|date=29 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Storms and plumes|url=http://www.weathercast.co.uk/weather-news/news/ch/29e17bbef4dde02d107df89925fddb20/article/storms_and_plumes.html|publisher=MeteoGroup|accessdate=18 December 2012}}</ref> *2013, 26–27 July A [[Mesoscale convective system]] developed in France and moved across the Netherlands and northern Germany, a gust of 102 mph was recorded at [[Pauillac]], France from the storm. Smaller scale thunderstorms developed in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|last=Penston|first=Seán|title=Heavy and thundery rain across Ireland and the UK|url=http://www.weathercast.co.uk/weather-news/news/ch/13adca3a39064f4ecccaaaa82c7e145b/article/heavy_and_thundery_rain_across_ireland_and_the_uk.html|accessdate=30 July 2013|newspaper=Meteogroup:Weathercast|date=27 July 2013}}</ref> *2014, 7–11 June [[2014 Pentecost weekend storms in Europe|Pentecost weekend storms in Europe]] brought disruptive conditions across France, Belgium and Germany where 6 fatalities were recorded as a [[Bow Echo]] swept through [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] with winds up to 144 km/h.<ref>{{cite news|title=Supercells over parts of France brought severe thunderstorms, large hail and flash flooding from 7–9 June.|url=http://www.eumetsat.int/website/home/Images/ImageLibrary/DAT_2238698.html|accessdate=10 June 2014|publisher=EUMETSAT|date=10 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Un week-end de Pentecôte marqué par une forte activité orageuse|url=http://www.meteofrance.fr/actualites?articleId=7603794|accessdate=10 June 2014|publisher=Météo France|date=10 June 2014|language=French}}</ref> *2014, 17–21 July severe storms left at least two fatalities in France, with power cut to thousands of homes and localised flooding occurring in France and the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lightning strikes and heavy rain over the weekend|url=http://metofficenews.wordpress.com/2014/07/21/lightning-strikes-and-heavy-rain-over-the-weekend/|accessdate=22 July 2014|publisher=Met Office|date=21 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mills|first1=Ian|last2=Lancaster|first2=Sancha|title=Very hot, moist conditions triggered thunderstorms and lightning over parts of Europe in mid-July.|url=http://www.eumetsat.int/website/home/Images/ImageLibrary/DAT_2280408.html#ir|accessdate=22 July 2014|publisher=EUMETSAT|date=22 July 2014}}</ref> *2015, 30 June–4 July A plume brought high temperatures from Spain across France and the UK. In France some July temperature records were set, and in the UK some all time maxima were set in some locations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vague de chaleur : des températures record|url=http://www.meteofrance.fr/actualites/26520660-vague-de-chaleur-des-temperatures-record|accessdate=2 July 2015|publisher=Météo-France|date=2 July 2015|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=2 July 2015 – Record breaking hot weather for July in the UK|url=http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/news/releases/archive/2015/hot-july|accessdate=2 July 2015|publisher=Met Office|date=2 July 2015}}</ref> Severe thunderstorms also moved northwards across the UK on 1 July and again overnight 3–4 July.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lewis|first1=Matthew W.|last2=Silkstone|first2=Nicholas|title=Improvements in nowcasting capability: analysis of three structurally distinct severe thunderstorms across northern England on 1 July 2015|journal=Weather|date=April 2017|volume=72|issue=4|pages=91–98|doi=10.1002/wea.2837|bibcode=2017Wthr...72...91L}}</ref> *2016, 6–7 June A Spanish plume event brought extensive thunderstorm activity across the UK and Ireland,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/weather/10975669/Lightning-storm-hits-UK-and-Ireland-with-spectacular-lightshow-in-pictures.html|title=Lightning storm hits UK and Ireland with spectacular lightshow, in pictures|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-05-24|language=en}}</ref> resulting in the hospitalisation of a man and his children after being struck by lightning in Lisburn, Northern Ireland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-36553339|title=Lisburn lightning strike: George Allen 'continuing to fight', family says|date=2016-06-16|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-05-24|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==Similar regional set-ups==
===Mexican Plume=== A similar pattern, though on a larger scale, is the Mexican plume in the south west USA, where hot dry air from the Mexican highlands acts as a cap to convection until lifted over Texas, Arkansas and Oklahoma.<ref name="Carlson" /><ref name="OUP" >{{cite web|title=Oxford Index: Spanish Plume|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100521301|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Oxford Reference: Mexican plume|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100154578|publisher=Oxford Reference|accessdate=11 April 2013}}</ref>
===Eastern Baltic=== In [[Finland]] and the [[Baltic states]] meteorologists have observed a situation conducive to severe summer storm development which occurs when a warm moist air mass flows into the region from the south or south east under the influence of an upper-level trough. These conditions have some similarities to the Spanish plume.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Punkka|first=Ari-Juhani|author2=Marja Bister |title=Occurrence of Summertime Convective Precipitation and Mesoscale Convective Systems in Finland during 2000–01|journal=Monthly Weather Review|year=2005|volume=133|issue=2|pages=362–373|doi=10.1175/MWR-2854.1|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/full/10.1175/MWR-2854.1|accessdate=28 November 2012|bibcode = 2005MWRv..133..362P }}</ref> The synoptic conditions see a low over southern [[Norway]], bringing warm south and southwesterly flows of air up from the inner continental areas of [[Russia]] and [[Belarus]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tuovinen|first=Jari-Petteri |author2=Ari-Juhani Punkka |author3=Jenni Rauhala |author4=Harri Hohti |author5=David M. Schultz|title=Climatology of Severe Hail in Finland: 1930–2006|journal=Monthly Weather Review|year=2008|volume=137|pages=2238–2249|doi=10.1175/2008MWR2707.1|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/2008MWR2707.1|accessdate=7 May 2013|bibcode = 2009MWRv..137.2238T }}</ref>
==Animated descriptions of Spanish plume== * [http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/learning/learn-about-the-weather/weather-phenomena/spanish-plume Met Office: What is a Spanish plume?] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/feeds/27704153 BBC Weather: Spanish Plume, what is it and how does it form with Darren Bett] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110509010150/http://news.bbc.co.uk/weather/hi/news/newsid_9476000/9476279.stm BBC Weather Player 'Spanish Plume' brings rain to the UK]

{{Infobox short story <!--See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]]--> | name = The Heathen | image = | caption = | title_orig = | translator = | author = [[Jack London]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = Short story | published_in = ''[[Everybody's Magazine]]'' | publication_type = Magazine | publisher = | media_type = | pub_date = 1910 | english_pub_date = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | preceded_by_italics = | followed_by_italics = }} "'''The Heathen'''" is a short story by the American writer [[Jack London]]. It was first published in ''[[Everybody's Magazine]]'' in August 1910,<ref>{{isfdb title|id=612289|title=The Heathen}}, accessed 15 November 2015.</ref> and later included in the collection of stories by London, ''The Strength of the Strong'', published by [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan]] in 1914.<ref name=jlnet>[http://www.jacklondons.net/writings/StrengthStrong/contents.html ''The Strength of the Strong''] The World of Jack London, accessed 15 November 2015.</ref>
In the story, two people, from different cultural and racial backgrounds, are the only survivors of a ship that encounters a hurricane in the Pacific, and they remain together.
==Background== In 1907 London began a voyage across the [[Pacific Ocean]] in his [[ketch]] the ''Snark'', and visited islands in the south Pacific, concluding the voyage in Sydney, Australia. He wrote about the adventure in his book ''[[The Cruise of the Snark]]''. "The Heathen" is set among islands that London visited during that period.
==Plot summary== The narrator, a pearl buyer named Charley, is a cabin passenger on a [[schooner]], the ''Petite Jeanne'', sailing from [[Rangiroa]] to [[Tahiti]] with a [[Kanaka (Pacific Island worker)|Kanaka]] crew, at the end of the pearling season in the [[Paumotuan|Paumotas]]. The boat, having eighty-five deck passengers, is overloaded. Several passengers die of [[smallpox]]; Charley and the other cabin passengers drink whisky, until it runs out, in the belief that it will kill the smallpox germs.
The boat is in the direct path of a hurricane. "The second sea filled the ''Petite Jeanne'''s decks flush with the rails, and, as her stern sank down and her bow tossed skyward, all the miserable dunnage of life and luggage poured aft. It was a human torrent.... Out of all my experiences I could not have believed it possible for the wind to blow as it did.... It was a monstrous thing, and the most monstrous thing about it was that it increased and continued to increase."
The ''Petite Jeanne'' is destroyed in the hurricane, and Charley survives by clinging to a hatch cover from the boat, sharing it with a Kanaka named Otoo. Eventually Charley loses consciousness, and comes to on the beach of an [[atoll]]; Otoo has saved his life by pulling him from the water. They are the only survivors from the ''Petite Jeanne''.
They exchange names. "In the South Seas such a ceremony binds two men closer together than blood-brothership." They part in [[Papeete]] and Otoo goes home to [[Bora Bora]]; but he returns, because his wife has died. He accompanies Charley for the next seventeen years, ensuring that he does not come to harm.
"Truly, he made me a better man. Yet he was not strait-laced. And he knew nothing of common Christian morality.... he was a heathen... a gross materialist who believed that when he died he was dead. He believed merely in fair play and square-dealing.... Otoo had my welfare always at heart. He thought ahead for me, weighed my plans and took a greater interest in them than I did myself."
Otoo advises Charley to become a captain of a schooner, in order to save enough to own a plantation. He does so; he marries and has children. Otoo helps to bring up the children on the plantation.
The relationship ends when Otoo is killed saving Charley from sharks on the coast of [[Savu]]. "And so passed Otoo, who saved me and made me a man, and who saved me in the end."
==Commentary== In a 2006 collection of stories by London including "The Heathen", the editors comment: "In the early 1940s, when this story found its way into fiction anthologies and high school textbooks, it was admired for its fiercely detailed picture of a storm at sea and for its courageous examination of a friendship that transcended cultural and racial differences.... It is nowadays impossible for us to read the account of the friendship between Charley and Otoo so simply.... By the 1970s, as editors began to see the complexity of the ideas about race embedded in "The Heathen", it simply became easier to drop the story from collections altogether." <ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=n2obXkYcSPcC&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=jack+london+the+heathen pp129–130] Jack London, Gary Riedl and Thomas R. Tietze, ''Jack London's Tales of Cannibals and Headhunters'', UNM Press, 2006, accessed 24 November 2015.</ref> ==References== {{Wikisource|The Heathen}} {{reflist}}
